Jay Stickmen Retain Title
By Downing Maryland, 6-3;
To Meet Hillmen Thursday
DON KELLY LEADS
WITH THREE GOALS
Old Liners Unsuccessful In
Belated Last-Quarter
Rally

—Courtesy The Sun
COACH RAY VAN ORMAN

Kelly Scores First

Yearley To Lang

Millard Lang led the Jay attack in
the third quarter with two goals.
The first came after three minutes
of play when Church Yearley caught
Lang open on the right of the crease
and fired a perfect pass to him. Rufus Vincent retaliated for the Old
Liners by scooping up a loose ball in
a scrimmage and "shoveling" it past
Mac Brogden. Shortly before the
period ended Yearley and Lang
teamed again to provide Hopkins
with a 6-1 lead going into the final
session.
Noted as a strong finishing team,
Maryland lived up to its reputation
by counting twice and holding its
rival in check. The Terps chalked
up their second goal by the expedient of a speedy triple pass, with Bill
Wood on the shooting end. Their
final point was made by the same
stickman, who shot from an angle
after breaking loose around the
crease. Hopkins was content to resort to defensive play and was at ru?
time in serious trouble.
Jay Defense Efficient

The Bluejay defensive corps pe-:formed as efficiently as ever, completely smothering the efforts of
such Terrapin stars as Skip Faber,
Pugh and Hc4ensmith. Reynolds and Yearley made their usual
sorties downfield to speed the ball
to the attack. All in all, however,
Capt. Moke Merriken was the best
all-around defenseman on the field.
For Maryland, Pfau, Norwood
Sothoron, and Bill Wood gave the
most convincing exhibitions. 'The

William Reid, president of the
Senior Class, announced the following f0mi for application for entry
in the June Week regatta, June 9:

With the view in mind of improving The Black and Blue Jay,
the Johns Hopkins University chapter of Pi Delta Epsilon, national
honorary college journalism fraternity, yesterday, announced a contest
for contributions to the campus
magazine.
A prize will be awarded to what
is judged to be the best contribution,
whether it be a cartoon, short story,
poem, or essay. Other entries,
whether awarded a prize or not, are
to become the property of the magazine and will be used, if suitable, in
the 1933-34 issues, Philip P. Hamburger, editor-in-chief of the monthly publication, indicated.
Entries in the contest, designed to
arouse a greater interest in The Jay
and to encourage contributions to it
from undergraduates, graduate students, faculty members, alumni, and
friends of the Hopkins, are to be
forwarded, postage prepaid, to Hyman Levin, P. 0. 675, The Johns
Hopkins University.

London "Times" Correspondent
Will Speak At I.N.A. Banquet

Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington
correspondent to the London Times
and the only English newspaperman
ever knighted by the Crown, has accepted an invitation to speak at the
formal banquet of the Intercollegiate Newspaper Association of the
Middle Atlantic States, to be held
November 18, the closing day of the
fall convention at the Johns Hopkins University.
Governor Albert C. Ritchie and
Mayor Howard W. Jackson have
also accepted invitations to attend
the dinner, which is to be attended
by editors and business managers
from 26 college papers. Edwin C.
Hill, Columbia Broadcasting System commentator, has written, according to Hyman Levin, president
of the I. N. A., that he will not
know whether he can accept the invitation definitely until the close of
summer.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., TUESDAY, MAY 23, 1933

Vol. XXX VII, No. 38.

An attack that struck with deadly
force during the last six minutes
of the second period earned the
Johns Hopkins lacrosse ten a 6-3
triumph over the University of
Maryland last Saturday, and enabled
the Jays to retain their national title
for the second consecutive year.
Neither team had displayed the
necessary tallying punch in the opening quarter, and seemed destined to
end the half in a scoreless deadlock.
Then in a flash the Homewood offense lashed out with all its fury,
and registered four times before the
half-time gun interrupted the bombardment. From this point on,
Maryland was a beaten team.

Readjustments in the S. A. C.
budgets amounting to a saving of
over $2500 were finally sanctioned
by the Student Activities Council
last Friday. The revisions were the
outcome of several months of investigation by a committee of five
men appointed by Omicron Delta
Kappa, national honorray activities
fraternity, and headed by J. Milton
Smith, president of the S. A. C.
Out of nine campus groups affected, eight will operate on reduced
budgets next year and one, THE
NEWS-LETTER, Will have an increased appropriation in order to
allow it to continue on its normal
semi-weekly schedule. The extent
of the subsidy to be granted Levering Hall has not yet been determined, and the Cotillion Board,
which will be operated as a regular
activity in the future, is still unprovided for.
Cotillion Board Taken Over

According to the plans developed
by Smith and his committeemen,
Douglas Stone, president of 0. D.
K.; Charles Squire, secretary of the
S. A. C.; Hyman Levin, former
editor Of THE NEWS-LETTER; and
Dr. J. C. Hubbard, of the School of
Engineering Faculty, it was suggested that the Cotillion Board be taken
over by' the Council and all its expenses and profits made part of the
Council's financial structure. The
purpose of this, Smith said, was to
make the Board more strictly a campus group, functioning for the benefit of the Hopkins student.
Notable among the activities cut
were the Hullabaloo and the Debating Council. The stipend for
the year book amounted this year
to $1700, but has been cut to $500
for 1933-34. This is possible, T. S.
Stern, editor for next year, explained, because it is expected that
the Senior Class will bear the entire
burden of the book's production
through its class dues, and the student body as a whole will not have to

The reason for this action of the S.
A. C. was plain enough. Some of its
members have been waiting for the
chance for many moons to put the skids
beneath campus debating, claiming that
it does not have student interest behind
it and is consequently a waste of money.
These members may be conscientious
enough but that does not excuse their
not recognizing that in debating lies one
of the best opportunities for acquiring
goodwill for the Hopkins in circles
where it will be really significant.
A moment's thought brings to .mind
that the Hopkins has a great name in
intellectually appreciative circles. Opponents of the Blue Jay forensic squads
expect formidable showings, and these
are certainly not possible if the squad is
not allowed sufficient funds to carry out
even a moderately extensive season.
Since it is in the interest of every undergraduate that his university be well represented, it is only logical that he should
be willing to support every reasonable
effort toward that end. This point the
S. A. C. men have overlooked.
The beginning of the new Council's
operations has certainly not been auspicious. It's no credit to it that the body
of the committee's report was accepted;
that was the logical reaction to the authoritative and intelligent work done by
Milton Smith and his committiteraen.
Our only hope is that the Administration will veto the faux pas and that the
Council will get tself in lina—by next
year.

The Last Issue
WITH THIS issue we conclude publication Of THE NEWS-LETTER for the
current semester. We know it's not your
fault, but you'll have to take it manfully.
The next issue will appear in your
post box on the- Second day of the new
term, Tuesday, October 3.

CAM PUS
13PEVITIIS

TUESDAY, MAY 23, 1933,

Review
THE IMMINENCE of exams brings
us up sharply with the realization that
another year has slithered through our
fingers. Conscientious souls on the campus will try to recall what has been outstanding and worthwhile about the whole
thing and will meet with the usual obstacles in trying to convince themselves
that anything has happened.
Herein, of course, lies our golden opportunity: we'll undertake to point out
just a few reminders of the gloriOus mediocrity we have been experiencing.
Beer, of course. And it receives the
instant approbation of those two roguish
connoisseurs, Williamson and Post, who,
though they can't buy it in Levering,
will defend to the death their right to
drink it there . . . The Dean takes up
pipe-smoking in a big way . . . Schaal,
with nothing in the world to worry
about, is now in a position to greet everyone with a big grin . . . President
Ames deals a crushing blow to the
vanity of instructors by telling them that
their maximum appointment is for five
years . . . and arouses our suspicions by
the haste with which he emphasizes that
the faculty pay-cut was purely voluntary
. . . And U. of M, finds moral satisfaction in the face of physical defeat by
painting a big M on the bowl ... Stern,
rising young politician, as he emerges on
the top of the heap is heard to say that
"this politic1.1 business is perfectly disgusting" . . . as a business, yes.
Our department for research in matters of feminine pulchritude reports that
the girls are getting plenteous and beauteous, but that they are entirely too easy
to pick up .. . Seniors, with the depression what it is, consider flunking and
persuading the pater to keep them in college for another year ... and the editor,
in the last issue of the year, takes a
shocking relapse.
An uneventful year, most decidedly.
And future years promise to maintain
their past consistency in this matter until
Dr. Mitchell is able to arouse us to the
poignancy of socialism as an economic
cure-all.

IN ACTING upon the recommendations of the 0. D. K. committee for the
readjustment of the budgets the Student
Activities Council has not particularly
signalized its intelligence or its foresightedness. The committee put in a lot
of valuable time in research of the problems of appropriations and advanced
very sensible ideas on the matters of the
control of the Cotillion Board and the
possibility of an optional fee. 'Yet the
S. A. C. ignored its recommendations
for the Debating Cauncil budget and
1 voted it a 64 per cent cut.

Tau Beta Pi's Slant on HONOR SYSTEM
.11.•••••••••••••••••••••

•••••••••••

As the school year draws to its
close, Tau Beta Pi wishes to take
this opportunity to officially express
its opinion of the Honor System at
Hopkins and, at the same time, to
offer a few suggestions that we believe would lead to its improvement.
We feel that a pure Honor System, where all matters of conduct
are left for each student to decide
for himself, is not a feasible one; a
plan that offers a greater chance for
success is one that is based primarily on the Honor System, but at the
same time has incorporated in it
some of the better points of the
proctor. The Student Council is
evidently of somewhat the same
opinion itself, as an inspection of
the more recent regulations will reveal.
The object of any system of student control should be to bring before the student body the real value
of always conducting themselves in
a straightforward, gentlemanly
fashion. This is, obviously, best
accomplished with an honor system; but in providing the necessary
enforcement measures it should be
borne in mind that a too severe penalty for violations will, in the end,
defeat the very purpose of the system, because it will lead toward a
suppression, rather than a correction, of dishonest practices. Also,
too strict a penalty plan will tend to
make fellow students loathe to report offenders.
We believe that the present system at Hopkins leans too much toward such a "strong arm" method
of enforcement. A somewhat more
lenient and more well defined system of penalties would, in our opinion, result in a much more satisfactory operation of the Honor System.
Just because a student has cheated
once in his career is no indication
that he is inherently dishonest and
a single moderately severe penalty
will often serve to bring a first ofhas moved eastward. If you like Denny,

System shall be the immediate infliction of a "council failure" in the
course in which the violation occurred." Such a failure would bar
the student from the course for the
remainder of the semester while
giving him an unconditional failure
for the course.
2. "The penalty for conviction
for a second violation of the Honor
System shall be the same as for a
first offense; except that in flagrant
violations the council shall have the
right to cause immediate expulsion."
3. "The penalty for conviction
for a third violation of the Honor
System shall be immediate expulsion."
4. "In each trial for dishonest
practices in the classroom, one faculty member shall sit as a member
of the council, ex-officio. This faculty member shall be chosen from
the division of the University in
which the student standing trial is
enrolled."
One recommendation that we have
to make is entirely out of the jurisdiction of the Council: that recommendation is, that in all subjects, the
emphasis placed upon final examination be reduced to a minimum. If
this were carried out, a great tempttation would be removed from the
path of those students who are on
the border line; and who, when exthe border line.
In the problem of leaving the
room during quizzes and examinations we believe that the faculty
member under whom the quiz or
exam is given should have the authority to allow a student to leave
the room for sufficient reason.

WE HAVE ALWAYS harbored a
Peeve for Baltimore drivers as being the
most reckless automaniacs who ever
made the streets unsafe for poor pedestrians like ourselves, but we'll have to
award the gilt-edged summons for the
height of something a other to the
driver of that Cadillac roadster which
furnished us with a few exciting moments in Washington the other morning.
WE WERE STROLLING innocently
up the Avenue and were just venturing
timidly across the no man's land of a
filling station driveway when said driver
of said Cadillac executed a well-timed
flank attack. His tanks were full and
so was he, and he was outbound for
the nearest emergency hospital. Leaving
behind us the better part of a handful of
assorted books and papers we had been
carrying, we stood not upon the order
of our going. That is to say, we departed
from the spot with a speed which astonished even ourself.
FROM A VANTAGE point on a
lawn where our flight had taken us, we
watched the remainder of the short but
amazing career of "this accident which
was so rapidly going somewhere to happen. Describing a course resembling a
slightly disproportionate letter S. the
roadster approached the nearest intersection which, to complicate matters, was
crossed by a car track. To make things
even more intereiting, a street car was
at the same time coming up.
IT WAS A grand race — while it
lasted. But all good things must come
to an end, and this. contest was no exception. The honors for speed were equally
divided as, with a crash of broken glass,
the race ended in a tie.
WE ARRIVED THERE just as they
picked him up and were dusting the
windshield out of his hair. He wasn't
hurt; they never are. grie he seemed
supremely insulted over something.'
'SHAY," he said, turning belligerently to the motorman, "shay, didn't you
hear me honk my horn? Whay don't
you get out of a fella's way?"

will bring their season to a close

confident of snapping the Black and
Blue's winning record.

teamed again to provide Hopkins
with a 6-1 lead going into the final

by counting twice and holding its
rival in check. The Terps chalked
up their second goal by the expedient of a speedy triple pass, with Bill
Wood on the shooting end. Their
final point was made by the same
stickman, who shot from an angle
after breaking loose around the
crease. Hopkins was content to resort to defensive play and was at ru?
time in serious trouble.

Pugh and Hc4ensmith. Reynolds and Yearley made their usual
sorties downfield to speed the ball
to the attack. All in all, however,
Capt. Moke Merriken was the best
all-around defenseman on the field.
For Maryland, Pfau, Norwood
Sothoron, and Bill Wood gave the

Readjustments in the S. A. C.
budgets amounting to a saving of
over $2500 were finally sanctioned
by the Student Activities Council
last Friday. The revisions were the
outcome of several months of investigation by a committee of five
men appointed by Omicron Delta
Kappa, national honorray activities
fraternity, and headed by J. Milton
Smith, president of the S. A. C.
Out of nine campus groups affected, eight will operate on reduced
budgets next year and one, THE
NEWS-LETTER, Will have an increased appropriation in order to
allow it to continue on its normal
semi-weekly schedule. The extent
of the subsidy to be granted Levering Hall has not yet been determined, and the Cotillion Board,
which will be operated as a regular
activity in the future, is still unprovided for.
Cotillion Board Taken Over

According to the plans developed
by Smith and his committeemen,
Douglas Stone, president of 0. D.
K.; Charles Squire, secretary of the
S. A. C.; Hyman Levin, former
editor Of THE NEWS-LETTER; and
Dr. J. C. Hubbard, of the School of
Engineering Faculty, it was suggested that the Cotillion Board be taken
over by' the Council and all its expenses and profits made part of the
Council's financial structure. The
purpose of this, Smith said, was to
make the Board more strictly a campus group, functioning for the benefit of the Hopkins student.

burden of the book's production

The reason for this action of the S.
A. C. was plain enough. Some of its
members have been waiting for the
chance for many moons to put the skids
beneath campus debating, claiming that
it does not have student interest behind
it and is consequently a waste of money.
These members may be conscientious
enough but that does not excuse their
not recognizing that in debating lies one
of the best opportunities for acquiring
goodwill for the Hopkins in circles
where it will be really significant.
A moment's thought brings to .mind
that the Hopkins has a great name in
intellectually appreciative circles. Opponents of the Blue Jay forensic squads
expect formidable showings, and these
are certainly not possible if the squad is
not allowed sufficient funds to carry out
even a moderately extensive season.
Since it is in the interest of every undergraduate that his university be well represented, it is only logical that he should
be willing to support every reasonable
effort toward that end. This point the
S. A. C. men have overlooked.
The beginning of the new Council's
operations has certainly not been auspicious. It's no credit to it that the body
of the committee's report was accepted;
that was the logical reaction to the authoritative and intelligent work done by
Milton Smith and his committiteraen.
Our only hope is that the Administration will veto the faux pas and that the
Council will get tself in lina—by next
year.

TUESDAY, MAY 23, 1933,

Review
THE IMMINENCE of exams brings
us up sharply with the realization that
another year has slithered through our
fingers. Conscientious souls on the campus will try to recall what has been outstanding and worthwhile about the whole
thing and will meet with the usual obstacles in trying to convince themselves
that anything has happened.
Herein, of course, lies our golden opportunity: we'll undertake to point out
just a few reminders of the gloriOus mediocrity we have been experiencing.
Beer, of course. And it receives the
instant approbation of those two roguish
connoisseurs, Williamson and Post, who,
though they can't buy it in Levering,
will defend to the death their right to
drink it there . . . The Dean takes up
pipe-smoking in a big way . . . Schaal,
with nothing in the world to worry
about, is now in a position to greet everyone with a big grin . . . President
Ames deals a crushing blow to the
vanity of instructors by telling them that
their maximum appointment is for five
years . . . and arouses our suspicions by
the haste with which he emphasizes that
the faculty pay-cut was purely voluntary
. . . And U. of M, finds moral satisfaction in the face of physical defeat by
painting a big M on the bowl ... Stern,
rising young politician, as he emerges on
the top of the heap is heard to say that
"this politic1.1 business is perfectly disgusting" . . . as a business, yes.
Our department for research in matters of feminine pulchritude reports that
the girls are getting plenteous and beauteous, but that they are entirely too easy
to pick up .. . Seniors, with the depression what it is, consider flunking and
persuading the pater to keep them in college for another year ... and the editor,
in the last issue of the year, takes a
shocking relapse.
An uneventful year, most decidedly.
And future years promise to maintain
their past consistency in this matter until
Dr. Mitchell is able to arouse us to the
poignancy of socialism as an economic
cure-all.

Tau Beta Pi's Slant on HONOR SYSTEM
.11.•••••••••••••••••••••

As the school year draws to its
close, Tau Beta Pi wishes to take
this opportunity to officially express
its opinion of the Honor System at
Hopkins and, at the same time, to
offer a few suggestions that we believe would lead to its improvement.
We feel that a pure Honor System, where all matters of conduct
are left for each student to decide
for himself, is not a feasible one; a
plan that offers a greater chance for
success is one that is based primarily on the Honor System, but at the
same time has incorporated in it
some of the better points of the
proctor. The Student Council is
evidently of somewhat the same
opinion itself, as an inspection of
the more recent regulations will reveal.
The object of any system of student control should be to bring before the student body the real value
of always conducting themselves in
a straightforward, gentlemanly
fashion. This is, obviously, best
accomplished with an honor system; but in providing the necessary
enforcement measures it should be
borne in mind that a too severe penalty for violations will, in the end,
defeat the very purpose of the system, because it will lead toward a
suppression, rather than a correction, of dishonest practices. Also,
too strict a penalty plan will tend to
make fellow students loathe to report offenders.
We believe that the present system at Hopkins leans too much toward such a "strong arm" method
of enforcement. A somewhat more
lenient and more well defined system of penalties would, in our opinion, result in a much more satisfactory operation of the Honor System.
Just because a student has cheated
once in his career is no indication
that he is inherently dishonest and
a single moderately severe penalty
will often serve to bring a first ofhas moved eastward. If you like Denny,

WE HAVE ALWAYS harbored a
Peeve for Baltimore drivers as being the
most reckless automaniacs who ever
made the streets unsafe for poor pedestrians like ourselves, but we'll have to
award the gilt-edged summons for the
height of something a other to the
driver of that Cadillac roadster which
furnished us with a few exciting moments in Washington the other morning.
WE WERE STROLLING innocently
up the Avenue and were just venturing
timidly across the no man's land of a
filling station driveway when said driver
of said Cadillac executed a well-timed
flank attack. His tanks were full and
so was he, and he was outbound for
the nearest emergency hospital. Leaving
behind us the better part of a handful of
assorted books and papers we had been
carrying, we stood not upon the order
of our going. That is to say, we departed
from the spot with a speed which astonished even ourself.
FROM A VANTAGE point on a
lawn where our flight had taken us, we
watched the remainder of the short but
amazing career of "this accident which
was so rapidly going somewhere to happen. Describing a course resembling a
slightly disproportionate letter S. the
roadster approached the nearest intersection which, to complicate matters, was
crossed by a car track. To make things
even more intereiting, a street car was
at the same time coming up.
IT WAS A grand race — while it
lasted. But all good things must come
to an end, and this. contest was no exception. The honors for speed were equally
divided as, with a crash of broken glass,
the race ended in a tie.
WE ARRIVED THERE just as they
picked him up and were dusting the
windshield out of his hair. He wasn't
hurt; they never are. grie he seemed
supremely insulted over something.'
'SHAY," he said, turning belligerently to the motorman, "shay, didn't you
hear me honk my horn? Whay don't
you get out of a fella's way?"

Prospects for next year appear
promising. Only two members of
the squad, Chassin and Milstone,
will be lost through graduation.

achieved by this year's team. Chassin's successor to the captaincy was

Burbage will serve as junior manager.
The department of athletics
has officially announced that the
1933 football practice season will
begin Wednesday, September 6th.
Coach Ray Van Orman desires
all men in the university who are
interested in playing football to
report for practice at 2.30 on the
above date. An intensive schedule has already been arranged.

by the rough tactics applied by both
teams. Time had to be called upon
three occasions, when Packard,

will bring their season to a close
against Mount Washington at
Homewood Field. A hard-fought
battle is in prospect, with little to
choose between the two combinations. The Hillmen have added to

of the 1932 Hopkins ten, and are
confident of snapping the Black and
Blue's winning record.

team of the United States and Canada. It is expected that Hopkins
